desc: ACCESS AND INSPECTION OF RECORDS AND PROPERTY; SUBMISSION OF ITINERARIES.
narrative:
Records not available for inspection. Licensee and supervisory personnel not present, and workers had no access
to records. Acquisition / disposition records, written program of veterinary care, and any treatment records must be
available at time of inspection.
CORRECT FOR FUTURE INSPECTIONS

desc: CLEANING, SANITIZATION, HOUSEKEEPING, AND PEST CONTROL.
narrative:
Utility/prep area in lower kennels had several unlabeled spray bottles containing various substances. Unlabeled
bottles can result in accidental misuse of products, which can result in harm to animals. A system must be in place
to ensure substances used around animals are properly labeled and safely used.
CORRECT BY: 5-25-14
Exit interview conducted with facility personnel.

desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
narrative:
The last site visit and review of the Program of Veterinary Care, (PVC), by the attending veterinarian was over 1 year ago
(9-16-2022). The Program of Veterinary Care should be reviewed and updated as necessary to accommodate new
animals/species, facility changes, new regulations, and/or changes in husbandry practices.
Each dealer and exhibitor shall employ an attending veterinarian under formal arrangements. In the case of a part-time
attending veterinarian or consultant arrangements, the formal arrangements shall include a written program of veterinary
care and regularly scheduled visits to the premises of the dealer or exhibitor.
Correct by November 2, 2023.

desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
narrative:
The following medications were past the labeled expiration date: cephalexin 250 mg - expired in 2021, cephalexin 500mg
expired on 8-21-2023. These medications were intermingled with other products that are currently being used at the
facility and are therefore considered ready for use.
Expired drugs are not an appropriate method to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries. The licensee
must ensure that all medications used in the facility are not expired, labeled properly in accordance with standard
veterinary practices, and are stored in accordance with manufacturer recommendations.
Correct by November 2, 2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.

desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
narrative:
At the time of the inspection, only three of the sixteen dogs listed on the APHIS 7005 Dogs on Hand Form were present at
the facility. The staff representative said that the dogs are kept with other trainers and are not usually present at the
inspection site. No itineraries have been submitted for the other 13 dogs not available for inspection.
Any person who is subject to the Animal Welfare regulations and who intends to exhibit any animal at any location other
than the person’s approved site (including, but not limited to, circuses, traveling educational exhibits, animal acts, and
petting zoos), except for travel that does not extend overnight, shall submit a written itinerary to the Deputy Administrator.
The itinerary shall be received by the Deputy Administrator no fewer than 2 days in advance of any travel and shall
contain complete and accurate information concerning the whereabouts of any animal intended for exhibition at any
location other than the person’s approved site. If the exhibitor accepts an engagement for which travel will begin with less
than 48 hours’ notice, the exhibitor shall immediately contact the Deputy Administrator in writing with the required
information. APHIS expects such situations to occur infrequently, and exhibitors who repeatedly provide less than 48
hours’ notice will, after notice by APHIS, be subject to increased scrutiny under the Act.
Correct by September 10, 2024

At the time of the inspection, it was found that 15/16 dogs had not been vaccinated yearly for Bordatella as required by
the attending veterinarian as written in the program of veterinary care. The last date of Bordatella vaccination was
documented to be on 6-20-2023 for 14 dogs and on 4-19-2023 for one dog. Requirements for preventive care must be
followed as directed by the AV.
Vaccinations for contagious and/or deadly diseases of dogs (including rabies, parvovirus and distemper) and sampling
and treatment of parasites and other pests (including fleas, worms, coccidia, giardia, and heartworm) in accordance with a
schedule approved by the attending veterinarian.
Correct by September 10, 2024

At the time of the inspection, medical record files were only available for 3 of the 16 dogs listed on the dogs on hand
APHIS 7005 form.
Dealers, exhibitors, and research facilities must keep copies of medical records for dogs and make the records available
for APHIS inspection.
These records must include: The identity of the animal, including identifying marks, tattoos, or tags on the animal and the
animal’s breed, sex, and age; Provided, however, that routine husbandry, such as vaccinations, preventive medical
procedures, or treatments, performed on all animals in a group (or herd), may be kept on a single record; If a problem is
identified (such as a disease, injury, or illness), the date and a description of the problem, examination findings, test
results, plan for treatment and care, and treatment procedures performed, when appropriate;
The names of all vaccines and treatments administered and the dates of administration; and the dates and
findings/results of all screening, routine, or other required or recommended tests or examinations.
Correct by September 10, 2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.

desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
narrative:
An authorized responsible adult was not available to accompany APHIS Officials during the inspection process at 2:04 pm
on Thursday, April 3rd, 2025. The inspector attempted to contact the licensee by phone and text messages and waited
until 2:38 pm before leaving the premises without receiving reply from licensee. Failure to provide access to the facility,
animals, and records for inspection is a serious violation of the AWA and regulations. Failure to comply may result in
enforcement action.
End Section

desc: ATTENDING VETERINARIAN AND ADEQUATE VETERINARY CARE.
narrative:
The program of veterinary care provided was incomplete. It did not list veterinary care procedures for all the
regulated species present at the facility within the past year (bushbabies were listed, but not sheep, rabbits, or
cattle). Furthermore, information was not provided about when reglarly scheduled visits by the attending
veterinarian would be made. A vague program of veterinary care can contribute lack of approprate and timely
treatment for ill animals. There were, in addition, no written provisions for emergency care in this document.
Research facilities employing a consulting veterinarian must have a written program of veterinary care listing all
regulated species and documented regularly scheduled visits to the research facility. To be corrected by 2/26/2014.

desc: ATTENDING VETERINARIAN AND ADEQUATE VETERINARY CARE.
narrative:
During inspection of the bush baby facility several bottles of expired medications were found mixed with unexpired
drugs. This included antibiotics and a topical spray expired for more than 30 days. Expired medications shall not be
used for the treatment of regulated animals as they can cause unintentional illness. Expired medications must be
clearly labeled as expired and separated from current medications, or properly disposed of.

There were at least two ceiling lights in one of the rooms of the bush baby facility with a coating of black film
material that was peeling off. As one of these lights was located over a corner of a bushbaby cage, pieces of the
black film material could fall off into the cages and cause injury to the animals (ingestion etc.). Housing facilities for
nonhuman primates must be kept inn good repair and must protect the animals from injury. To be corrected by
2/26/2014.
There was an electrical outlet in a room of the bushbaby facility that was missing a cover. As water is often used in
cleaning the facility, this could present a hazard to regulated animals or laboratory staff. Housing facilities for
nonhuman primates must be kept inn good repair and must protect the animals from injury.To be corrected by
3/12/2014.
The exit briefing was conducted with the Director of ORI.
Additional Inspectors
Gaj Gregory, Supervisory Animal Care Specialist

desc: Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC).
narrative:
The semiannual program review from November 2019 and June 2020 noted minor deficiencies regarding the cage
washer. The reports did not contain a schedule with dates for correcting these deficiencies. Deficiencies noted during the
semiannual program review must include a plan and timeframe for correction, in order to ensure the timely and complete
correction of problems identified. Correct on September 25th, 2020, by including reasonable and specific plans and
correction dates for all deficiencies identified during future semiannual program reviews and facility inspections.

desc: Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC).
narrative:
Protocol 15101501, approved on October 25, 2018, states that sheep will be housed for the duration of the protocol at a
facility not owned or operated by the University. This facility was not included in the semiannual facility inspections and
program reviews conducted in November 2019 or June 2020. Inspection of animal housing facilities is important to ensure
animals are housed in facilities that are appropriate, safe, and in compliance with the applicable regulations under the
Animal Welfare Act. Correct on September 25th, 2020, by including all animal housing facilities in future semiannual
program reviews and facility inspections.

desc: Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC).
narrative:
Protocols 15101501, 17101206, and 18022801, did not include a rationale or explanation for the species used. A rationale
is required in order to demonstrate the appropriateness of the species selected for use in research. Correct on September
25th, 2020, by including a rationale for the species of animals to be used in research protocols.

The 2019 annual report submitted by the institutional official to USDA APHIS Animal Care included 0 rabbits and 0 sheep.
The USDA inspection conducted in July 2019 included the observation of two rabbits at the research facility. These
rabbits were not included on the 2019 annual report. Facility representatives stated that these rabbits were used in study
17101206, and should have been reported in column D on the 2019 annual report. Facility representatives reported that in
fiscal year 2019, 4 rabbits were used in total and should have been reported in column D. Facility representatives also
reported that 6 sheep were used in fiscal year 2019 which should have been reported in column D. Correct reporting of
information on the annual report is required so that the public and Congress can have knowledge of the number, type,
and pain category of animals used- or held for use in research. Correct by September 30th, 2020, by submitting a
corrected annual report to USDA APHIS Animal Care.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
End Section

The semiannual program review from November 2020 noted a minor deficiency regarding the cage washer. The report
did not contain a schedule with dates for correcting this deficiency. Deficiencies noted during the semiannual program
review must include a plan and timeframe for correction, in order to ensure the timely and complete correction of
problems identified. Correct by including reasonable and specific plans and correction dates for all deficiencies identified
during future semiannual program reviews and facility inspections.

desc: Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC).
narrative:
Protocol 15101501, which is active and was approved on October 25, 2018, states that sheep will be housed for the
duration of the protocol at a facility not owned or operated by the University. This facility was not included in the

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.

Gervais Edmonds-Wiggins, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICEREnd Section

The facility's annual report for FY 2022 did not accurately report all animals used or held for research. The FY 2022
annual report reported 10 hamsters (all in Column D) and zero rabbits. Review of facility records of animal acquisition and
disposition showed that the facility used 1 rabbit in May 2022 which should have been reported in Column D. Facility
records also show that a total of 19 hamsters should have been reported in Column D, and 9 additional hamsters should

Correct reporting of all required information on the annual report is required so that the public, USDA APHIS Animal Care,
and Congress can have knowledge of the number, type, and pain category of animals used- or held for use in research.

No training records had been completed for staff working with the marine mammals. While some of the staff caring
for the animals had been doing so for as much as 10 years, the facility had not documented any of their training.
The facility should ensure that training records are maintained and made available for review by APHIS officials so
that said officials may assess the qualifications of facility staff.
Correct by April 15, 2015.
An exit briefing was conducted with a facility representative.

Some defects were observed on the surfaces inside the monk seal pool. The inspector returned to the facility on
3/22/17, when the pool was scheduled to be drained. Upon viewing the drained pool it was clearly evident that some
areas of the wall and floors of the pool have significantly deteriorated. On the wall, there are at least a dozen large
patches measuring up to five inches in diameter or more, where the original surface is missing, and the underlying
concrete has a roughened surface. On the floor, there are at least two areas where the surface has also failed,
including one two foot by one foot rectangle where eighty percent of the original surface is missing, and the
underlying surface is uneven and rough.
Failure to maintain the surfaces in good repair could result in ingestion of materials coming off of the pool walls and
floor, an inability to adequately clean and disinfect the surfaces, roughened pool bottom that could cause abrasions,
especially when the pool is drained, and / or the possibility of contaminants leaching through the unsealed,
deteriorated areas in the pool surface, which could affect water quality. Any of these could be detrimental to the
health and well-being of the animals.
Whereas the facility has contracted an architect to come up with plans for improvements to this exhibit, there is
currently no documented timeline for performing maintenance on the pool surfaces.
All surfaces in a marine mammal primary enclosure must be constructed of durable, nontoxic materials that facilitate
cleaning, and disinfection in order to maintain the desired water quality. All surfaces must be maintained in good
repair as part of a regular, ongoing maintenance program.
To be corrected by November 20, 2017.
This inspection was conducted on 3/20/17 and 3/22/17, and the inspection and exit interview were conducted with
facility representatives.

On April 20, 2024, a peregrine falcon was unexpectedly startled during a presentation and escaped from its handler. The
handler had removed the bird from its travel enclosure, and the falcon panicked with a gust of wind and the handler lost
control of the restraint devices. The falcon was not recovered despite efforts to retrieve it. Escaped animals may suffer
physical harm, trauma, and stress. The facility must address handling to ensure animals are handled as expeditiously and
carefully as possible to minimize these risks. Corrective actions made by the facility included re-assessing exhibitions
during high winds and creating procedures for outdoor raptor handling, and searches.
Correct by 06/17/2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with Facility Representative.

desc: ATTENDING VETERINARIAN AND ADEQUATE VETERINARY CARE (DEALERS AND EXHIBITORS).
narrative:
One cinnamon colored male Chihuahua that the facility representative estimated at 15 years old (microchip number
086-333-327) has a heavy coating of dark brown matter on his upper teeth. The dog was also missing all of its
bottom teeth. The abnormal buildup of material on the teeth can cause damage to the gum tissue and tooth
structure, be painful, impact the ability of the dog to eat normally and harm the health of the animal. The licensee
must have this animal examined by a veterinarian and appropriate plan administered. The outcome of this
examination must be documented and provided to the inspector upon request. The licensee must ensure that all
animals receive adequate veterinary care at all times.
To be corrected by August 11, 2014.
Exit interview conducted with facility representative at time of inspection.

desc: INSTITUTIONAL ANIMAL CARE AND USE COMMITTEE (IACUC).
narrative:
*** Protocol 256: A procedure was performed on a species not specified in the approved animal use protocol. Any
changes to a protocol must be reviewed and approved by the IACUC prior to conducting any activity associated with
the change. An IACUC review of protocol changes is to ensure that animals do not experience unnecessary pain
and distress and to verify that personnel are adequately trained to handle and conduct procedures on a particular
specied. The IACUC must amend the protocol to include goats as a species and/or implement appropriate
procedures to ensure protocol changes are reviewed and approved by the IACUC for all protocol deviations
involving the use of animals.
Correct by May 30, 2014.
NOTE: The goat did not experience any pain or distress as it was a terminal procedure performed under
anesthesia.

desc: ATTENDING VETERINARIAN AND ADEQUATE VETERINARY CARE (DEALERS AND EXHIBITORS).
narrative:
***Protocol 229: Rabbits on the study failed to receive a prescribed medical treatment for a day and a half.
Treatment for a medical condition must be adminsiterd as indicated by the atending veterinarian. Personnel must be
trained on the procedures for identifying animals on treatment according to facility standard operating procedures to
ensure the veterinarian's prescribed treatment is administered in a timely manner. Correct by April 18, 2014
An exit briefing was conducted with the facility representatives.

desc: ATTENDING VETERINARIAN AND ADEQUATE VETERINARY CARE (DEALERS AND EXHIBITORS).
narrative:
Expired medications were found as follows:
SPF Clinic: 3 jars of Erythromycin tabs-exp 5/8/15, 1 vial Vit B inj-exp 7/15, 1 Gentocin spray-exp 7/11, 10 tubes of
Vetropolycin oint-exp 4/15, 1 vial of Aminophyline-exp 6/1/15
Conventional clinic: 1 jar of Erythromycin tabs-exp 5/8/15, 2 bottles of Amoxicillin--exp 1/15, 2 vials Cetazolin-exp
9/14.
Additionally, a vial of Penicillin G inj is currently being used to treat primates BA 74, AD 65, BP 15, & BK 19. When
this was discovered by this inspector during the inspection the veterinarian immedialtey changed the treatment to a
different antibiotic.
Expired medications are considered adulterated, and their use is not an appropriate method to prevent, control,
diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries.
The facility currently has a system for identifying expired medications, but it appears that this system is not entirely
effective. Institute improvements to assure that expired medications are removed and not administered to any
animals.
Correct immediately

On June 28, 2015, a person (or persons) entered the facility and facilitated the escape of 11 primates from their
enclosure. Ten of these primates were either captured or returned to their enclosure on their own. One primate is
still missing.
The facility inspected the perimeter fence and did not find any cuts or openings along the fence. An inspection of
the perimeter fence today showed that there was a space between the 2 service gates adjacent to the enclosure
which could be moved a few inches by hand. There was also a space between the bottom of another service gate
and the ground near enclosures 163/164 which also can be moved a few inches by hand. The perimeter fence is
not 6 feet high on the left side of the old feed bunker, and this section shall be raised to at least 6 feet high.
The perimeter fence shall restrict unauthorized persons (and animals) from entering the facility and having contact
with the animals. The perimeter fence shall be at least 6 feet high along its entire length.
Since this incident, the facility has provided additional security measures.
Correct by September 1, 2015
This was a partial inspection. The exit interview was conducted with the attending veterinarian.

desc: INSTITUTIONAL ANIMAL CARE AND USE COMMITTEE (IACUC).
narrative:
Protocol # A1500116 & 9040115 do not contain complete descriptions of the proposed use of the animals, nor does
it contain the actual numbers of animals that will be studied. These activities involving primates are reportedly a
continuation of other PI's terminated work but there is no mention of this in either protocol.
All protocols must contain a complete description of the proposed use of animals and the rational for such use. If a
protocol is an exact continuation of previous work, that shall be so stated in the protocol and available for review
during an Animal Welfare inspection. Any deviations to those previous protocols shall also be completely
described.
Correct by July 24, 2016

desc: ATTENDING VETERINARIAN AND ADEQUATE VETERINARY CARE.
narrative:
Primate 8Q6 was observed to have an opacity in the right eye. The vet techs indicated that he was born with large
eyes and has been this way since birth. They are continuously observing this condition. This condition, however,
was never reported to the attending veterinarian for examination, and has never received any veterinary care. The
veterinarian is the person who is qualified to assess the animal's health and well-being, and is the one who would
determine if an animal is suffering, or is experiencing pain &/or distress. He is also the one who would decide
whether no treatment, treatment, or euthanasia is appropriate.
A mechanism of direct and communication is required so that timely information on problems with animal health and
well-being is conveyed to the attending veterinarian so that he may determine if this animal is in pain, distress or
suffering; and to decide whether veterinary examination, care, or euthanasia is appropriate.
Correct immediately

Recently a mainland operator is offering jet ski tours to the public which stops a few hundred feet offshore from the
island. The participants get off of their jet skis and then snorkel in the shallow waters. There is photographic
evidence that some of these participants actually gained access onto the island.
The primates can become stressed due to observing new people. This stress reaction can possible alter the
behavioral research that is being conducted. There is also a health risk to the public if the primates should attack,
bite, scratch, defecate or urinate on them since they can be on the ground, overhead in the trees, or in the water. It
is also known that some of the primates on this island are Herpes positive which also poses an additional health risk
to the jet ski participants.
The registrant has hired security to patrol these particular areas, but the security leaves the island mid day and
before these jet ski operations end for the day.
Additional security (or other) measures shall be established to ensure that the unauthorized persons cannot get
close or gain access to the island and make direct or indirect contact with the primates, so as to ensure both the
safety of the primates as well as the public. This can be accomplished (but not limited to) additional security,
erection of a fence or other type of barrier, or continuous video surveillance.
Correct by July 31, 2016
The exit interview was conducted on-site with the contact person.
The contact person had to leave before this inspection report could be completed. By mutual agreement, this
inspection report will be E mailed to the contact person.

According to the minutes from April 2016, there was an incident on April 15, 2016 in which 4 NHP escape from their
primary enclosure.
Two NHP were captured the same day, one the next day and the other one on July 22.There was no injury to the
animals and they stayed within the perimeter area of the facility.
Handling of all animals shall be done as expeditiously and carefully as possible in a manner that does not cause
behavioral stress, or unnecessary discomfort.
The situation has been corrected by retraining the employees, changing the padlock system by using color coded
padlocks and controlling who has the keys and by having security guards recheck the enclosure padlocks during the
rounds they make around the facility.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.

desc: INSTITUTIONAL ANIMAL CARE AND USE COMMITTEE (IACUC).
narrative:
Protocol # A170316 contains a list of various teaching procedures that may be performed on the animals. Several
of these procedures are only described generally in the protocol, and do not contain a complete description of the
work that may be performed.
All protocols must contain a complete description of the proposed use of the animals.
Correct by March 10, 2017
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the Clinical Veterinarian

The horizontal tube at the bottom of several gates in the primate enclosures (SPF section), had flaky rust and
jagged edges.
In order to prevent injury to the primates if their fingers come in contact with the rusted jagged edges and to
preserve the structural strength of the enclosure, facilities must be kept in good repair.
To be corrected by 7-1-2017.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.

The lack of adequate husbandry and animal care practices animal during the University’s Union incident during February
17th and 18th, 2022 was noncompliant with the handling of animals under the regulations of the Animal Welfare Act
(AWA); four nonhuman primates died, and one nonhuman primate had escaped when personnel/normalcy returned to the
premises. According to facility reports to the IACUC, on February 17th, a hospitalized animal was found dead in her
treatment cage approximately at 11:00am; five hours overdue for medical treatment (staff normally starts at 6:00am). A
report to the IACUC on February 18th stated that another two animals were found dead in their respective enclosures;
carcasses not removed from enclosures until late (cause of deaths unknown). Early on February 17th, an animal was
identified as injured by his conspecifics, but was not removed from its enclosure or treated until after 3:00pm; facility
veterinarians humanly euthanized the animal on February 19th due to poor prognosis. Also early on February 17th, an
animal escaped its enclosure, and was observed attacking other animals from other enclosures; the animal was not
trapped until after 3:00pm. Failure to handle animals appropriately can lead to deteriorating health and welfare, including
escapes and death. The facility shall be able to handle animals at all times expeditiously, carefully, and in a manner that
does not cause trauma, behavioral stress, or physical harm to members of the nonhuman primate colony, by providing the
AWA-required husbandry and animal care practices.
To be completed by: July 23, 2022

Due to the University's Union incident on February 17th and 18th, 2022, the entrance to the Sabana Seca site premises
was blocked, preventing access of required/essential personnel to the facility. Only up to four out of the total 20 qualified
facility personnel were able to enter the facility during the two days of the incident, which resulted in the delivery of
inadequate husbandry and animal care services to a colony of over 2,300 nonhuman primates. As a result, four
nonhuman primates died; two found dead in their enclosures, one found dead in the facility's hospital, and one died by
humane euthanasia two days after due to complications of traumatic injuries by conspecifics. Any facility subject to the
Animal Welfare Act regulations must have enough employees to carry out the level of husbandry practices and care at all
times. The lacking in number and adequately trained employees can lead to inadequate husbandry and care to
nonhuman primates, posing a risk to their health and welfare. Also, in order to handle nonhuman primates, sufficient
number of employees must be trained and supervised by an individual who has the knowledge, background, and
experience in proper husbandry and care of nonhuman primates to supervise others. The research facility must be
certain that the supervisor can perform to these standards.
To be completed by: August 22, 2022
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with two facility representatives.

desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
narrative:
Several metal roof planks from the investigator’s office, and two animal shade platforms were observed to have extensive
corroded sharp points and edges. Buildings and facilities at premises where nonhuman primates congregate and use,
must be kept in good repair, and be free of jagged edges or sharp points in order to protect the animals from traumatic
injuries. To prevent potential injuries to the nonhuman primates in the colony, the facility must repair or replace as all
corroded roof planks on all affected buildings within the premises.
To be completed by: September 25, 2022
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with three facility representatives.
n

During inspection, APHIS officials were reviewing the registrant’s IACUC meeting minutes, and the record of attendance
was not found on February 7, 2025, and March 7, 2025. The records are important to keep track of who’s attending the
meetings and to make sure the non-affiliated member has a chance to express their opinion. The research facility shall
maintain records of the minutes of IACUC meetings, including records of attendance, activities of the Committee, and
Committee deliberations.
Correct by August 7, 2025.

During inspection, APHIS officials noticed in the cage washroom the aluminum ceiling had multiple areas of rust with
holes ranging from 1cm to 3 inches where sunlight was seen coming through. The supporting beams were also rusted.
The holes on the roof are big enough where pests have an entrance point and have access to animals, equipment, and
rooms. Housing facilities for non-human primates must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound
for the species of non-human primates housed in them. They must be kept in good repair, and they must protect the
animals from injury, contain the animals securely, and restrict other animals from entering.
Correct by November 20, 2025
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with Facility Representative.
Additional Inspectors:
KRISTIN NAPOLI, SUPERVISORY ANIMAL CARE SPECIALIST n

During inspection, APHIS officials noticed multiple walls in different primary enclosures with peeling paint. In other primary
enclosures multiple tiles of the floor were seen with missing pieces and sharp edges. The pieces of paint can be ingested
and affect the animals' health and well-being. The missing pieces from the tiles on the floor can cause injury if the feet or
hands of the animals were to get entrapped in these spaces. The housing facilities for the non-human primates must be
constructed and maintained in a way to protect the non-human primates contained in housing facilities. Housing facilities
for nonhuman primates must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound for the species of
nonhuman primates housed in them. They must be kept in good
repair, and they must protect the animals from injury, contain the animals securely, and restrict other animals from
entering.
Correct by November 30, 2025.

During inspection, APHIS officials were reviewing the IACUC meeting minutes from January 17, 2025, and they noticed
the following adverse event:
On December 5, 2024, a total of 24 animals escaped from corral 166-A from side gate that was not properly locked. 17 of
24 animals were captured the same day within 4 – 5 hours (12-5-24). Three (3) animals were captured (on) 12-6-24 and
additionally on Dec 7, 9, and 10, 2024 were captured and had to be euthanized due to the potential threat of introducing
unwanted pathogens to the colony. There is still one animal from the corral that hasn’t been captured but has been seen
around the perimeter of the facility. On the March 7, 2025 IACUC meeting one of the last two animal was captured.
However, after talking with the attending veterinarian it had to be euthanized due to having spent time outside the
perimeter fence. According to the Attending Veterinarian one animal is still missing and has not been captured by the time
of the inspection.
It is important that all gates and latches be kept in good repair and firmly secured to prevent opportunities for animals to
escape or injure themselves. The primary enclosures should be maintained to contain the non-human primates securely
and prevent accidental opening of the enclosure, including opening by the animal.
Corrected by the time of inspection.

desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
narrative:
During inspection, APHIS officials observed 15 – 20 cats in the area outside the veterinary clinic, kitchen area, and right
outside the walk-in cooler unit where vegetables, fruits, and seeds are kept. Cats are known vectors of diseases, such as
toxoplasma that can affect the health and well-being of the rhesus macaques kept at the facility. Officials also noticed cat
food placed directly on the floor in the area outside the walk-in cooler which can attract other types of pests. An effective
program for control of insects, external parasites affecting nonhuman primates, and birds and mammals that are pests,
must be established and maintained so as to promote the health and well-being of the animals and reduce contamination
by pests in animal areas.
Correct by September 22, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with Attending Veterinarian.
Additional Inspectors:
KRISTIN NAPOLI, SUPERVISORY ANIMAL CARE SPECIALIST n

desc: ACCESS AND INSPECTION OF RECORDS AND PROPERTY; SUBMISSION OF ITINERARIES.
narrative:
A responsible adult was not available to accompany the APHIS Official during the inspection process at 3:45 pm -
4:15 pm on 09/10/2014.
No one responded to knock on door or when I honked the car horn. Left message on voicemail.

None of the outdoor shelters contained enough bedding. There was a small amount of shavings in most of the
shelters, but not enough to even cover all of the floor in some of the shelters. The ambient temperature at the time
of the inspection was 41 degrees F, but had gotten down to 33 degrees F the night before. The licensees stated
that they had not added any bedding to the shelters since the previous spring. Inadequate bedding can result in
dogs becoming too cold, which can adversely affect the health of the animals. The licensee must ensure that all
dogs are provided with clean, dry bedding material if the ambient temperature is below 50 degrees F and additional
clean, dry bedding when the temperature is 35 degrees F or lower.
This item must be corrected by November 28, 2018.

Three adult German shepherd dogs had inadequate shelter. Two of the dogs were in an enclosure with one shelter
structure that was of inadequate size for both dogs. The other dog had a shelter structure that was too small for the
dog. Inadequate shelter doesn't provide enough protection from the wind and cold, which can affect the health of
the dogs. The licensee must provide shelter structures that allow each dog enough space to sit, stand, and lie in a
normal manner and to turn about freely.
To be corrected by November 30, 2018.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.

There was inadequate ventilation in the whelping building. The whelping building is a converted reefer trailer with a door
on one end and a small window and air conditioner unit on the other end that was unplugged. Upon entering, there was
an ammonia odor that got stronger as the inspectors progressed towards the back of the trailer. Both inspectors had
burning eyes and one inspector's eyes began to water by the time we got to the end of the trailer. Strong ammonia levels
can lead to respiratory issues and burning and sensitivity in the eyes. Indoor housing facilities must be sufficiently
ventilated at all times to minimize odors and ammonia levels to provide for the health and well-being of the animals.
Correct by 11/4/22 by properly ventilating the kennel building at all times.

There were multiple broken wires and sharp points protruding into several kennels containing dogs. Seven enclosures
containing 11 dogs had broken wire flooring or wire ties pointed into the enclosures that the dogs could step on or brush
up against. Two kennels containing 2 dogs had solid aluminum sheeting between 2 adjacent enclosures that had been
bitten, chewed, and pulled up, creating sharp edges. Three kennels containing 4 dogs had metal feeders with wire hooks
protruding into the enclosure, right at eye level next to the food. One of the feeder hooks had a large clump of fur stuck to
it. Sharp points could scratch or cut the skin, feet, or eyes of dogs in the enclosures. Primary enclosures must be
constructed and maintained so that they have no sharp points or edges that could injure the dogs. Correct by 10/30/22 by
ensuring that no primary enclosures contain sharp points.

In the whelping building, 3 separate primary enclosures containing 4 dogs had broken flooring, creating holes large
enough for feet to fall through or become entrapped. The holes ranged from 2" x 2" to 2" x 3". Wire flooring in disrepair
can cause injury if dogs' feet fall through. Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that they protect the
dogs from injury. Correct by 10/30/22 by repairing the holes in the wire flooring.

In the whelping building, one dog, a dachshund named Black Satin did not have adequate space to exercise. The facility's
exercise plan is to group house dogs or provide individually housed dogs with twice the minimum required floor space.
Black Satin was 20" long, requiring a minimum of 676 square inches of floor space with additional opportunity for exercise
or doubled (1352 square inches of floor space) for exercise. Black Satin's primary enclosure was 36" x 36", providing
1296 square inches, falling short of the exercise requirement. Dogs must be provided with adequate exercise to promote
physical health and mental well-being. Dogs that are housed individually, must be provided twice the minimum space
requirement per the exercise plan. Correct by 10/28/22 by ensuring adequate space for exercise.

desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
narrative:
The licensee is not sanitizing primary enclosures in the whelping building at acceptable intervals. The licensee stated that
she sanitizes the enclosures before she moves a new dog into a used enclosure, which occurs when puppies are weaned
and new dogs are brought in before they whelp. She spot cleans daily but is not sanitizing at least every 2 weeks. When
enclosures are not sanitized, dirt, debris, and disease causing organisms can flourish and cause illness. Primary
enclosures must be sanitized at least once every 2 weeks using an appropriate method per the regulations, or more often
as necessary. Correct by sanitizing enclosures at appropriate intervals from this day forward.

The program of veterinary care did not list a sampling frequency for heartworms and no medical record existed to
demonstrate that heartworm testing is occurring. Testing is necessary to detect infections of heartworm, which is a
deadly and contagious disease. The program of veterinary care must direct and accurately reflect the prevention,
diagnosis, and treatment of diseases common in kennels, including rabies, parvo, distemper, fleas, intestinal worms,
coccidia, giardia, and heartworm. Correct by 11/30/22 by ensuring sampling and treatment protocols are written and
approved by the attending veterinarian in the program of vet care.

There were no medical records available to document the annual exam by the veterinarian. The attending veterinarian
performed his annual visit several months ago and provided a list of dogs needing dentals. No other record exists to
document the findings of the exams. Medicals records are important to track health history of dogs over time and ensure
complete and thorough treatment of medical conditions. Correct by maintaining medical records of all veterinary
encounters from this day forward.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
Brianna Waldrop, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
narrative:
Multiple dogs have not been given their prescribed antibiotics after their dental cleanings and extractions. At least 9
bottles of half to nearly full liquid clindamycin were in the medical supply months after they were prescribed. The
prescription labels stated to give until gone and were prescribed between September and December 2022. The licensee
stated that they stopped giving the medications once the dogs started eating again after their dentals. A phone call with
the Attending Veterinarian revealed that he did not authorize stopping the antibiotics. The use of medications such as
antibiotics after surgery can prevent disease such as abscesses and complications can arise when not used as
prescribed. The licensee must maintain adequate veterinary care by using appropriate methods to prevent disease.
Correct from this day forward.

Several primary enclosures containing dogs had broken wires and sharp points projecting inward. In the whelping
building, two enclosures containing 3 dogs had broken wire flooring that the dogs could step on. Emma, a pregnant
Papillon, was housed in an enclosure with an approximately 2" wire protruding from the floor. Two Yorkshire Terriers, a
male named Beau Jangles and a female named Grace, were housed in an enclosure with 2 broken wires approximately
1/2" in length protruding straight up from the floor. In the big dog kennel, wire is used to attach panels to posts. In 2
enclosures containing 4 dogs there was wire protruding into the kennels. Two Yorkshire Terriers, a male named Banjo
and a female named River Rose were housed in an enclosure with multiple wires ranging in 1" to 2" protruding into the
kennel at head height when the dogs stood up against the wall to play with their neighbors. Two Yorkshire Terriers, a
male named Jax and female named Dusty were housed in an enclosure with a 3-4" wire protruding just above head
height when the dogs stood flat on the ground. Sharp points can cause skin lacerations and eye injuries. Primary
enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that they have no sharp points or edges that could injure dogs.

In the whelping building, 3 primary enclosure containing 4 dogs had broken flooring, creating holes large enough for feet
to fall through or become entrapped. One enclosure, containing Terri, a pregnant Papillon, had a hole that was
approximately 3” x 1.5”. A female Yorkie named Gigi was in an enclosure with 2 holes approximately 1" x 2". Two yorkies,
a male named Beau Jangles and a female named Grace were housed together in an enclosure with a hole measuring 2"
x 1". Wire flooring in disrepair can cause injury to dogs if their feet fall through. Primary enclosures must be constructed
and maintained so that they protect the dogs from injury.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
COURTNEY JERNIGAN, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICEREnd Section

***Camel Barn: The barn has an excessive build up of excreta and organic debris. The camels did not seem to want
to enter the barn. Excreta and organic debris must be removed from primary enclosures as often as necessary to
prevent contamination and minimize disease. The excreta and organic material must be removed and a regular
schedule of removal must be established to ensure the camels have areas in the barn to stand and sit that is free of
excreta at all times. Correct by May 29, 2014.
An exit briefing was conducted with the owner.

desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
narrative:
A responsible adult was not available to accompany APHIS Officials during the inspection process at 2:00pm on
20FEB2024.
Called and spoke to the licensee. Licensee will be out of town until March 2024.
End Section

During the inspection, a rabbit was housed in the same primary enclosure as two tortoises.
Housing rabbits with other species of animals, such as reptiles, can expose them to potential disease hazards which can
affect their health.
Rabbits shall not be housed in the same primary enclosure with any other species of animals unless required for scientific
reasons.
Correct by: July 6, 2024.

desc: Primary enclosures used to transport live animals.
narrative:
The transport enclosures for the capybara and cavy did not have the words "Live Animal" or "Wild Animal" clearly marked
with arrows or other markings indicating the correct upright position of the enclosure.
A lack of clear markings can inhibit correct handling and cage orientation by first responders in the event of an
emergency.
The licensee must ensure that the words “Wild Animal” or “Live Animal” are marked on the top and on one or more sides
with letters at least 1 inch (2.5 cm) high, and have arrows or other markings to indicate the correct upright position of the
primary enclosure.
Correct by: July 8, 2024.
This inspection was completed at the Big Butler Fair in Prospect, PA.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee and facility representatives.

desc: ACCESS AND INSPECTION OF RECORDS AND PROPERTY; SUBMISSION OF ITINERARIES.
narrative:
***I arrived at the facility at 9:20 am and the gates were closed. I called the owner and he did not answer. I left a
message that I was at the facility to conduct an inspection. I waited for the customer for 30 minutes and called
again. There was no answer so I left a message that this would be an attemted inspection and that he would receive
the inspection report in the mail. I left the premises at 10:00 am. A responsible adult was not available and one
should have been available to accompany APHIS Officials during the inspection process at 9:20 am on 02/19/2014.

The facility has transported an adult male rhesus macaque into Tennessee to be sold at an exotic livestock auction.
No health certificiate executed and issued by a licensed veterinarian accompanied the macaque. A health certificate
is necessary when transporting a nonhuman primate in order to ensure that the nonhuman primate is free of
infectious disease or physical abnormality which would endanger the animal or other animals or endanger public
health. Correct from this day forward.
Inspection conducted at the exotic auction in Cookeville, TN.
Exit conducted with undersigned facility representative.
Additional Inspectors

desc: ATTENDING VETERINARIAN AND ADEQUATE VETERINARY CARE (DEALERS AND EXHIBITORS).
narrative:
***The program of veterinary has not been completed and signed by an attending veterinarian. Maintaining a
complete and accurate program of veterinary care is important in reflecting the current practices and procedures of
preventative care at the facility. Must consult with attending veterinarian to ensure adequate veterinary care. Each
exhibitor shall employ an attending veterinarian under formal arrangements. In the case of a part-time attending
veterinarian or consultant arrangements, the formal arrangements shall include a written program of veterinary care
and regularly scheduled visits to the premises of the exhibitor. Correct Immediately.

***There were no records documenting the acquisition of two pigs, a llama and other covered species and the
exhibitor shall make, keep and maintain records or forms which correctly disclose the information of these animals.
The records shall include any offspring born of any animal while in his or her possession or under his or her control.
Correct by August 9, 2014.
The inspection and exit interview was conducted with the owner.

** There were no records documenting the disposition of the male giraffe. The exhibitor shall make, keep and
maintain records or forms which correctly disclose the information of these animals. Correct by August 9, 2014.

** The prairie dog's exhibit allows the public to touch the animals through the wire mesh top. The owner also stated
that the prairie dogs can jump and grab the wire. For the safety of the animal and the public there needs to be a
public barrier to prevent them from putting their fingers through the wire. During public exhibition, any animal must
be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with sufficient distance and/or barriers
between the animal and the general viewing public so as to assure the safety of animals and the public. Correct by
September 3, 2015

desc: ENVIRONMENT ENHANCEMENT TO PROMOTE PSYCHOLOGICAL WELL-BEING.
narrative:
** The facility has not developed an appropriate plan for environment enhancement for the baboon and lemurs. The
exhibitors must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan for environment enhancement adequate to
promote the psychological well-being of nonhuman primates. The plan must be in accordance with the currently
accepted professional standards as cited in appropriate professional journals or reference guides, and as directed
by the attending veterinarian.This plan must be made available to APHIS upon request. Correct by August 27, 2015

** The perimeter fence that borders the giraffe barn has areas where outside animals can gain access to the park.
The perimeter fence consists of dead pine trees on the bottom third and cow panel on the top two-thirds. In some
areas there is a clearing between the pine trees and the cow panels that needs to be sealed to keep predators out
of the park for the safety of the animals. The fence must be constructed so that it protects the animals by restricting
unauthorized humans, and animals the size of dogs, skunks, and raccoons from going through it or under it. Correct
by September 3, 2015.
The inspection and exit interview was conducted with the owner.

desc: ATTENDING VETERINARIAN AND ADEQUATE VETERINARY CARE (DEALERS AND EXHIBITORS).
narrative:
** There were two great pyrenees puppies that was diagnosed with sarcoptic mange by the attending veterinarian.
They were being housed along with 3 young llama(cid:25)s. The attending veterinarian stated that she wanted all of the
animals to be treated with injectable ivermectin. Instead the llamas were treated with oral ivermectin by the owner.
The owner stated that he did not know that he was not supposed to treat the animals orally. Since the owner was
said to have already treated the animals the veterinarian was unable to treat with the injectable for fear of overdose.
There are no records of the oral ivermectin being given, the amount, dosage and route in which the medication was
administered to the animals. To ensure the proper medication was given and the condition was treated
appropriately the attending veterinarian should have the appropriate authority to make sure the provision of
adequate veterinary care has been given to the animals.

** There were no records documenting the acquisition and disposition of two great pyrenees puppies and 3 young
llamas. The exhibitor shall make, keep and maintain records or forms which correctly disclose the information on
these animals.
This was a focused inspection. The exit interview was conducted with the owner.

desc: ATTENDING VETERINARIAN AND ADEQUATE VETERINARY CARE (DEALERS AND EXHIBITORS).
narrative:
***The licensee uses a veterinarian under consulting arrangements to provide veterinary care for the animals but
does not have a formal agreement nor a written program of veterinary care. In order to ensure problems of animal
health are addressed adequately and timely, a written program of veterinary care must be maintained and followed.
Each licensee shall employ an attending veterinarian under formal arrangements. In the case of a part-time
attending veterinarian or consultant arrangements, the formal arrangements shall include a written program of
veterinary care and regularly scheduled visits to the premises of the licensee.

***The licensee did not have records that contained the required information regarding the correct number of
inventory, gender, age and location of animals on hand. Records containing the required information for animals
acquired for use in regulated activities, including those offspring born on premise, need to be made and maintained
in order to properly track the animal numbers and use in those activities.

desc: ENVIRONMENT ENHANCEMENT TO PROMOTE PSYCHOLOGICAL WELL-BEING.
narrative:
***An environmental enhancement plan to promote the psychological well-being of all non-human primates currently
housed at this facility has not been approved by the attending veterinarian. A written plan must be developed and
followed for all nonhuman primates. This plan must be in accordance with current accepted professional standards.
The inspection and exit interview was conducted with the licensee, Dr. Annette Chapman and Dr. Bart Sutherland
Additional Inspectors
Chapman Annette, Veterinary Medical Officer

On May 6, 2017 a kangaroo reached through the fence and scratched and bite a small child that was standing next
to the enclosure fence. There was no public barrier present to prevent an animal from reaching out of the enclosure
or to prevent someone from reaching into the enclosure. There must be some type of barrier to provide a sufficient
distance between the animal and the viewing public so as to assure the safety of the public. Correct immediately.
This focused inspection of the kangaroo enclosure and exit interview were conducted with owner.

desc: ATTENDING VETERINARIAN AND ADEQUATE VETERINARY CARE (DEALERS AND EXHIBITORS).
narrative:
There was a dead piglet observed in a shed in the pig enclosure. When shown to the facility representative, he was
not aware the piglet had died. There was an accumulation of mud in the upper part of the enclosure where the shed
was located from recent rains. Several piglets were observed to have difficulty ambulating in the deep mud.
It is possible the excessive thick mud was a factor in the piglet’s death. The facility should be observing the animals
daily to be aware of any issues that may impact the health of animals and cause injury or death.
The facility corrected the issue during the inspection by placing a new shed in the lower part of the enclosure where
the ground was dry.
CORRECT BY: Corrected during the inspection.

There were incomplete records of acquisition and disposition.
Complete records of the animals currently being housed including their acquisition and disposition is necessary in
order to accurately track animals to ensure humane care and use of the animals.
Exhibitors must make, keep, and maintain records which fully and correctly disclose information concerning animals
purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or otherwise in his or her possession or under his or her
control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer or exhibitor.
CORRECT BY: 9-25-19

The enclosure housing the single lemur did not have a public barrier to prevent contact with the animal.
Such unauthorized contact poses a possible risk of injury to both members of the public and the lemur.
The facility must handle animals so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with sufficient
distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public so as to assure the safety of animals
and the public.
CORRECT BY: 9-4-19

desc: ENVIRONMENT ENHANCEMENT TO PROMOTE PSYCHOLOGICAL WELL-BEING.
narrative:
There was no program for environment enhancement for the 3 lemurs. There was one lemur being housed
individually and two lemurs being housed together. The single lemur was unable to see the other two lemurs.
Nonhuman primates have social needs and needs for environmental enrichment which, if not addressed, may lead
to negative effects on their psychological well-being.
Exhibitors must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan for environment enhancement adequate to
promote the psychological well-being of nonhuman primates. The plan must include provisions to address the
social needs of nonhuman primates which exist in social groups in nature.
CORRECT BY: 9-25-19

The fence around the giraffe enclosure at the top corner was disconnected from the corner post and in need of
repair. The fence around the oryx was bent over in one area and in need of repair. The fence at the perimeter of
the property adjacent to the road and containing the exotic hoofstock was in severe disrepair in one area. The
fence there was essentially missing, with logs piled to prevent animal escape and a piece of black plastic had been
used to span the gap.
Animal injury may result from fencing in poor repair or from attempts of the animal to escape through damaged
fencing or subsequent to their escape.
The facility must be structurally sound and be maintained in good repair.
CORRECT BY: Temporary correction-9-4-19. Permanent correction-9-25-19.

The animal feed was stored in two structures near the pig enclosure. Some of the food was stored in closed plastic
bins. However, there were several bags of feed that were being stored directly on the ground and the bags were
opened with no means of securing them closed. In addition, there were rodenticide chemicals in spray bottles being
stored directly above open bags of feed which could possibly contaminate the feed if the bottles leaked. A large
number of bags of feed were piled on the floor on top of each other and next to each other with no space
underneath or around the bags to allow cleaning.
Food contaminated by chemicals or through improper storage may have a negative effect on animal health and
welfare.
Supplies of food should be stored in a manner which adequately protects them against deterioration, molding, or
contamination by vermin.
CORRECT BY: 9-4-19.

There was a large amount of spilled feed on the floor of one of the animal feed sheds. There were numerous rodent
droppings observed on the floor of the sheds and on top of the refrigerators. The interior of the refrigerators in both
sheds, which were used to store some of the perishable animal feed items, contained unidentified residue and were
in need of cleaning. There were discarded items, used cups and other debris in the grain bin, which presently was
not used for food storage.
Inadequate cleaning and repair may adversely impact the health and welfare of the animals.
Premises must be kept clean and in good repair.
CORRECT BY: 9-4-19.

There was evidence of rodent activity, including numerous rodent droppings observed in the animal feed sheds and
observation of a rat removing a food pellet from a lemur enclosure.
Rodents may carry diseases that negatively impact the health and welfare of animals.
The facility must establish and maintain a safe and effective pest control program.
CORRECT BY: 9-4-19.
The inspection took place 27-28 August 2019.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
Additional Inspectors
Schnell Michael, Veterinary Medical Officer

Temporary corrections have been completed for the fence around the giraffe enclosure and the fence at the
perimeter of the property adjacent to the road. The fence around the oryx was still bent over in one area and in need
of repair. Animal injury may result from fencing in poor repair or attempts of the animal to escape through damaged
fencing. The facility must be structurally sound and maintained in good repair.

At approximately 1:00PM, the camel enclosure- which contained one camel- was in the direct sun and there was no
shade available to the camel. Lack of shade can contribute to heat stress or discomfort for the animal. The facility
shall provide sufficient shade by natural or artificial means. Correct by October 7th, 2019.

The camel enclosure, which contained one camel, did not provide any natural or artificial shelter. Shelter from
inclement weather is necessary to provide protection and comfort for the animal. The facility shall provide natural or
artificial shelter from inclement weather. Correct by October 7th, 2019.
This was a focused inspection on noncompliances cited on the previous inspection report. This inspection and exit
interview were conducted with the facility representative.
Additional Inspectors
Brunkhorst Susanne, Veterinary Medical Officer

There were incomplete records of acquisition and disposition.
Complete records of the animals currently being housed including their acquisition and disposition is necessary in
order to accurately track animals to ensure humane care and use of the animals.
Exhibitors must make, keep, and maintain records which fully and correctly disclose information concerning animals
purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or otherwise in his or her possession or under his or her
control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer or exhibitor.

The enclosure housing the single lemur did not have a public barrier to prevent contact with the animal. The wire
mesh of the enclosure is large enough that people could stick fingers or objects through the mesh. The lemur was
observed sticking his fingers through the wire. There was an area of the mesh where there was a larger opening,
which the licensee stated was to facilitate feeding treats to the lemur.
Unauthorized contact poses a possible risk of injury to both members of the public and the lemur.
The facility must handle animals so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with sufficient
distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public so as to assure the safety of animals
and the public.

The camel enclosure, which contained one camel, did not provide any natural or artificial shelter from inclement
weather. Shelter from inclement weather is necessary to provide protection and comfort for the animal. The facility
shall provide natural or artificial shelter from inclement weather.

The fence at the perimeter of the property adjacent to the road and containing the exotic hoofstock was not
continuous, was not structurally sound, and was not 6 feet tall in all areas. The perimeter fence was falling down in
some areas. There were multiple gaps between where different fencing materials came together.
Perimeter fencing prevents unauthorized entry of people and animals. Animal injury may result from poor fencing or
from attempts of the animals to escape through damaged fencing or subsequent to their escape.
Correct by: January 1, 2020.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility owner.
Additional Inspectors
Schnell Michael, Veterinary Medical Officer

desc: ACCESS AND INSPECTION OF RECORDS AND PROPERTY; SUBMISSION OF ITINERARIES.
narrative:
A responsible adult was not available to accompany APHIS Officials during the inspection process at 2:04PM on
24-FEB-20.
Arrived at 2:04PM. Honked, called out loudly, called and left message on office number and cell phone number.
Waited 30 minutes. Put leave-behind flyer on the gait. Left at 2:34PM.
Additional Inspectors
Arango Juan, Permit Specialist

Some of the fencing and structures in the blackbuck enclosure and the giraffe enclosure are in poor repair.
Approximately 15 feet of fence on the right side of the enclosure containing 15 blackbuck is bent or leaning over. The
fence is comprised of wooden posts and metal wire panels. A tree has fallen on the fence and in this area there were two
wire panels held together by a strap or tie. The edges of some of the wire panels have sharp points. There is an
approximately 12 foot by 12 foot wooden shelter structure in the blackbuck enclosure that has a sagging roof, and the
roof has become separated from the far wall.
The outdoor section of the enclosure housing one adult male giraffe is made of wood posts and metal wire panels. At
least 4 wooden boards within the fence are broken, and 2 more boards are falling down from the top of the fence. Two of
the boards have nails sticking out of them. Numerous posts are leaning outwards.
Adequate structural strength and regular maintenance of fences and shelter structures is important for animal comfort,
health, and wellbeing. Animals can escape or become injured by inadequate or poorly maintained fences, and shelter
structures that are falling down may fail to provide adequate shelter from the elements.
Correct by maintaining facilities and enclosures that are structurally sound and in good repair to protect the animals from
injury and contain the animals within.

In April 2020 one David's deer, two sika deer, and two sheep were killed by predators at the facility. Coyotes were
observed in the area around the time of the deaths, and a gap beneath the perimeter fence was found that appeared to
be dug out by coyotes, wild dogs, or other wildlife predators. The gap was identified and filled in with concrete and no
additional deaths have occurred due to predation since that time.
The perimeter fence beside the giraffe enclosure, next to the road, is in poor repair. The fence consists of 6 foot tall metal
wire fencing next to the road, with black plastic tarps in some areas. The metal fence has some gaps and openings and is
less than 6 feet tall in some areas. Inside the metal fence there is a partially competed solid wood fence, which is leaning
outwards in some areas. There are numerous trees, bushes, and vines close to the fence and touching the fence.
Animals who are not protected by an adequate perimeter fence may be injured, killed, or sickened by contact with wildlife,
unauthorized people, or stray animals. Animals who are killed by predators suffer from stress, pain, and injury or death.
Correct by maintaining a perimeter fence that is of sufficient height and strength to prevent access by unauthorized
people or animals, and which acts as secondary containment in the event that an animal escapes from its primary
enclosure.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility owner.
End Section

desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
narrative:
At 12:15PM USDA officials arrived at the premises to conduct a routine inspection. The licensee stated that the facility
was closed for the winter and that USDA officials would not be allowed to conduct an inspection until the facility was open
for business on March 1st. USDA officials explained that the facility must allow USDA inspections to occur during the
winter months, and reminded the licensee that this issue had been discussed at length last year. The licensee stated that
he was not open for business and that an inspection would not be allowed today. USDA officials stated that this would be
documented as a refusal of inspection which is a serious issue. The licensee stated that it wasn't a refusal because the
facility wasn't open for business. USDA officials explained that business hours must occur each week. The licensee
reiterated that no inspection would be allowed until March 1st.
This exit interview was conducted with the licensee.
End Section

desc: ACCESS AND INSPECTION OF RECORDS AND PROPERTY; SUBMISSION OF ITINERARIES.
narrative:
A responsible adult was not available to accompany APHIS Officials during the inspection process at 1415-1445 on
07/15/2014.

desc: ATTENDING VETERINARIAN AND ADEQUATE VETERINARY CARE (DEALERS AND EXHIBITORS).
narrative:
At least four juvenile black bears showed significant hair loss and demonstrated repeated episodes of scratching
while observed during the inspection. There were no skin lesions beyond the hair loss, and all of the bears
appeared otherwise healthy. Facility records indicate that there was a phone consultation with the attending
veterinarian on 10 January 2014 regarding the black bear cubs hair loss. At that time, records indicate the animals
were dewormed with ivermectin. However, since that initial treatment there is no indication of any further treatment
or diagnostic testing. Medical problems that persist despite initial treatment must be followed up with appropriate
care, including any necessary diagnostic testing. These affected black bears must be examined by the attending
veterinarian in a timely manner, and treated as necessary. Records of all examinations, testing, and treatments
must be maintained by the facility.

desc: ATTENDING VETERINARIAN AND ADEQUATE VETERINARY CARE (DEALERS AND EXHIBITORS).
narrative:
On the afternoon of 2 April 2014, a male black bear named " Crybaby " was found injured with a single 4-8 inch long
laceration located on his lower back. The attending veterinarian arrived that afternoon for initial treatment, which
included suturing the wound. On 5 April, the facility discovered the wound had dehisced. On 14 April the wound was
open and bleeding heavily per facility personnel. The facility contacted the veterinarian and it was decided that
euthanasia was the appropriate choice. The attending veterinarian arrived at the facility in the late afternoon of 15
April and the bear was euthanized.
The attending veterinarian physically observed this animal twice throughout the length of the treatment period, once
on the date of the original injury (2 April) and again on the date of euthanasia (15 April). When the sutures dehisced,
the licensee re-sutured the wound closed. The attending veterinarian did not re-evaluate the injury during this time.
When the sutures dehisced a second time the veterinarian was called to euthanize the animal. When an animal
does not adequately recover from an injury or respond to treatment, there must be timely and appropriate follow up
examination by the attending veterinarian so as to evaluate the health and welfare of the animal. Documentation of
the veterinarian(cid:25)'s follow-up evaluation or treatment shall be documented.
This was a focused inspection following an official complaint on an injured black bear. Inspection and exit interview
conducted with facility personnel.
Additional Inspectors
Cunningham Debbie, Veterinary Medical Officer
Tygart Michael, Supervisory Animal Care Specialist

One male tabby tiger cub born 7/17/2015 (19 days old) is located in a public viewing area next to older cubs that are
used for public contact. The tiger cub is housed in a play pen type enclosure with no secondary heating or cooling
method for climate control. The enclosure is located off to the side behind the public barriers, but it is still located in
front of the enclosures holding the tigers used for public contact. The public does not walk directly by the tiger cub in
the playpen, however there is a walkway approximately ten feet away from the tiger cub that the public uses to gain
access to the area of public contact for the older cubs. The licensee has contact with the general viewing public and
states he is the primary caretaker for all of the cubs. The licensee stated that there is no public contact with the
young cub. The license also stated the cub is typically located on the RV and not normally out in the public viewing
area.
AnimaIs this young in the absence of their parents are not able to adequately thermoregulate and exposure to
temperatures which may be comfortable for adults may still be detrimental to the health of young cubs. Exposure to
an excessive number of people and other animals at this young age poses a disease risk to the cub. Even indirect
exposure via the licensee who has contact with the members of the public and other animals can pose a similar risk
to the cub of this age. The practices described above do not constitute handling the cub as carefully as possible and
unnecessarily risks harm and discomfort. Young animals may appear to cope with temperature extremes, however
when they are this young they are not able to thermoregulate and exposure to certain temperatures can be
detrimental to the health of the animal. The licensee must ensure that tiger cubs of this age are handled as carefully
as possible in a temperature controlled environment that minimizes exposure to potential pathogens.
The licensee moved the animal to a climate controlled RV prior to the exit briefing.

On 15 May 2017 a female tiger escaped from an exercise enclosure in the rear area of the facility. The tiger was
discovered loose on the premises by an employee during evening feeding. The employee immediately retreated
and called an emergency code on the radio. No park visitors were present due to the late hour. The facility owner
and other employees responded immediately and located the tiger in a corner of the facility near the perimeter
fence. With her proximity to the perimeter fence, and the high danger if she was to escape the facility under cover
of darkness, the licensee made the decision to shoot and kill the animal. This was accomplished with a single
round from a rifle by the licensee.
The facility did not know how the tiger escaped from the pen. The enclosure is a common exercise yard in the
middle of multiple pens, recently built by the facility, and used by numerous animals in rotation. The fencing of the
enclosure meets current requirements for height on three sides. On the fourth side there was a narrow sheet metal
ledge along the inside of the fence. This ledge is actually the border of the metal roof of an adjacent set of pens
which extends through the exercise yard fence. The ledge is approximately a foot wide, and ten feet in height. The
facility has since removed this ledge, and there are no other obvious structural problems with the enclosure.
This was a focused inspection to address this specific incident. The exercise enclosure clearly failed to contain this
tiger. After her escape, the facility did react appropriately according to their emergency protocols. The facility also
immediately contacted their USDA inspector to self-report the incident. As mentioned, the facility removed the
sheet metal ledge following the focused inspection.
The facility must take all necessary steps to ensure the exercise enclosure and all other park enclosures are
sufficient to contain the animals.
Correct from this point forward.

The inventory of animals on hand was incomplete and must contain the license number of the entity from which the
animal was acquired. If the entity is not licensed or registered under the Animal Welfare Act then a complete
address and identification is required from the person whom it was purchased or otherwise acquired. Although
APHIS form 7019 is not mandatory to use, alternate inventory forms must contain all information required in 2.75 (b)
